description: From Middle English male, from Anglo-Norman male, Old French male (“bag, wallet”), from Frankish *malha (“bag”), from Proto-Germanic *malhō (“bag, pouch”), from Proto-Indo-European *molko- (“leather pouch”). Compare Dutch maal.

entries.meaning: (now regional) A bag or wallet. [from 13thc.]
examples: What, loo, man, see here of dyce a bale; / A brydelynge caste for that is in thy male!

entries.meaning: A bag containing letters to be delivered by post.
The material conveyed by the postal service. [from 17thc.]
examples: Don't forget to pick up the mail on your way.

entries.meaning: (dated) A stagecoach, train or ship that delivers such post.
The postal service or system in general. [from 17thc.]
examples: He decided to send his declaration by mail.

entries.meaning: (chiefly US, uncountable) The letters, parcels, etc. delivered to a particular address or person. [from 19thc.]
(uncountable) Electronic mail, e-mail: a computer network–based service for sending, storing, and forwarding electronic messages. [from 20thc.]
A trunk, box, or bag, in which clothing, etc., may be carried.
examples: “Fetch me the little private mail with the padlocks, that I recommended to your particular charge — d'ye hear?”

verbs.description: mail (third-person singular simple present mails, present participle mailing, simple past and past participle mailed)

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To send (a letter, parcel, etc.) through the mail.
(ditransitive) To send by electronic mail.
examples: Please mail me the spreadsheet by the end of the day.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To contact (a person) by electronic mail.
examples: I need to mail my tutor about the deadline.

description: From Middle English mayle (“mail armor”), borrowed from Old French maille (“loop, stitch”), from Vulgar Latin *macla, from Latin macula (“blemish, mesh”), probably from Proto-Indo-European *smh₁-tleh₂, from *smeh₁- (“smear, rub”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Armour consisting of metal rings or plates linked together.
examples: "That's funny looking mail, Sire," said Eustace."Aye, lad," said Tirian. "No Narnian dwarf smithied that.  […]

entries.meaning: (nautical) A contrivance of interlinked rings, for rubbing off the loose hemp on lines and white cordage.
Any hard protective covering of an animal, as the scales and plates of reptiles, shell of a lobster, etc.
examples: We  […]  strip the lobster of his scarlet mail.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) A spot on a bird's feather; by extension, a spotted feather.

verbs.description: mail (third-person singular simple present mails, present participle mailing, simple past and past participle mailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To arm with mail.
(transitive) To pinion.

description: From Middle English mal, male from Old English māl (“speech, contract, agreement”) from Old Norse mál (“agreement, speech, lawsuit”). Akin to Old English mǣl (“speech”). Related to Old English mǣlan (mell), maþelian (“to speak out, declare”). From *maþlą (“meeting-place”), possibly from Proto-Indo-European *meh₂d- (“to encounter, come”), if so related to meet, and moot.

entries.meaning: (historical) An old French coin worth half a denier.
(chiefly Scotland) A monetary payment or tribute.
(chiefly Scotland) Rent.
(chiefly Scotland) Tax.
